title: AB 332
content: The people of California enact the following. The Legislature finds that Californians are concerned about the costs of growing older, especially long-term care expenses. A majority of respondents cannot afford nursing home care, with concerns spanning across income levels and political affiliations. The Legislature intends to establish a task force to explore creating a statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Legislature aims to create a task force to investigate the feasibility of a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will be established in the Department of Insurance to design and implement the program, consisting of nine members including the commissioner and representatives from various healthcare sectors. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members, including the Director of the Department of Aging, four persons appointed by the Governor with specific expertise, one person appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly, and one person appointed by the Senate Committee on Rules. Task force members will not receive compensation, and meetings will be governed by the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act. The task force's responsibilities include investigating the feasibility of a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force, consisting of nine members, will not receive compensation and will adhere to the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act. The task force's responsibilities include exploring the design of a statewide long-term care insurance program, considering eligibility, benefits, financing, and interaction with publicly funded resources. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will explore the inclusion of a long-term care insurance program in the state disability insurance structure. This program could involve voluntary premium contributions, mandatory enrollment with an opt-out option, and providing basic insurance benefits for those with cognitive limitations. It aims to help individuals remain in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services and offsetting costs for adults with chronic conditions. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force aims to help individuals with limitations stay in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services and offsetting costs for adults with chronic conditions. Recommendations include evaluating benefits coordination with private health care coverage, preparing the long-term care workforce for growing demands, establishing a joint public-private system for accessibility, and recommending regulatory provisions for accessing long-term care insurance programs. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force aims to recommend key regulatory provisions for accessing long-term care insurance programs and establishing a statewide program. The task force will operate within existing budgetary resources and submit a report to the commissioner, Governor, and Legislature by July 1, 2017. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program and provide a report to the commissioner, Governor, and Legislature by July 1, 2017. An actuarial report on the recommendations must be produced by July 1, 2018, and private funds may be sought for implementation. This section will be in effect until January 1, 2019, unless extended or deleted by a later statute.
